channel.title: NYT > U.S. News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2022 The New York Times Company

item.title: West Point Has a K.K.K. Plaque Mounted Above Entrance to Science Hall
item.description: A special congressional commission that recommends the removal of Confederate symbols at U.S. military sites flagged the bronze plaque in a new report.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The U.S. Military Academy at West Point. A congressional panel flagged a plaque mounted at the entrance of Bartlett Hall Science Center that includes an image of a hooded figure and the words “Ku Klux Klan.”

item.title: Judge May Release Affidavit in Trump Search, but Only After Redaction
item.description: The possibility emerged after news organizations sought to unseal the affidavit submitted in support of the search warrant. Any public version of the affidavit could be heavily redacted.
item.media:credit: Saul Martinez for The New York Times
item.media:description: Deanna Shullman, a lawyer for a coalition of news outlets seeking to unseal the affidavit, outside the federal courthouse in West Palm Beach, Fla., on Thursday.

item.title: L. Lin Wood, a Trump Ally, Is Called to Testify in Election-Meddling Inquiry
item.description: Mr. Wood said he would appear before the special grand jury in Atlanta.
item.media:description: “I didn’t do anything wrong,” said L. Lin Wood, a trial lawyer. “I’ve got nothing to hide.”

item.title: Death in Navy SEAL Training Exposes a Culture of Brutality, Cheating and Drugs
item.description: The elite force’s selection course is so punishing that few make it through, and many of those who do resort to illicit tactics.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces

item.title: Our Latest Covid Poll
item.description: Americans on the left end of the political spectrum have become less anxious about Covid.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Gabby Jones for The New York Times
item.media:description: Times Square in July.

item.title: Alabama Pastor Is Arrested While Watering Neighbor’s Flowers, Video Shows
item.description: The Rev. Michael Jennings, a pastor of 31 years, had been watering petunias and hydrangeas when a neighbor called the police to report suspicious activity, his lawyer said.
item.dc:creator: Eduardo Medina
item.media:description: Alabama Pastor Michael Jennings watering his neighbor’s flowers, moments before he was arrested in May.

item.title: After a Long, Starring Run, Will Racism at Last Get the Hook?
item.description: We can no longer ignore the theater’s systemic inequities. But leaving them behind may remake the industry in unexpected ways.
item.dc:creator: Jesse Green
item.category: We See You, White American Theater (Theater Coalition)

item.title: Doug Mastriano’s Extremely Online Rise to Republicans’ Governor Nominee in Pa.
item.description: The G.O.P. candidate for governor of Pennsylvania deftly used Facebook to build a loyal right-wing fan base at the height of the pandemic. Will it be enough to win a competitive general election?
item.dc:creator: Charles Homans
item.media:credit: Maddie McGarvey for The New York Times
item.media:description: Although Doug Mastriano is perhaps better known for challenging the results of the 2020 presidential election, he built a loyal following with pandemic livestreams on Facebook.

item.title: Documents at Mar-a-Lago Were Moved and Hidden as U.S. Sought Them, Filing Suggests
item.description: The filing by the Justice Department paints the clearest picture to date of its efforts to retrieve documents from the former president’s Mar-a-Lago estate in Florida.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush, Charlie Savage, Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: The Justice Department included a photo of documents seized from former President Donald J. Trump’s Florida home in its court filing.

item.title: US Life Expectancy Falls Again in ‘Historic’ Setback
item.description: The decline during the pandemic is the sharpest in nearly 100 years, hitting American Indian and Native Alaskan communities particularly hard.
item.dc:creator: Roni Caryn Rabin
item.media:description: A patient who died of Covid was removed from an I.C.U. in Cleveland, Ohio.

item.title: Toxic Red Tide Kills ‘Uncountable’ Numbers of Fish in the Bay Area
item.description: A harmful algal bloom in the San Francisco Bay is killing fish, sharks and stingrays. Some are washing ashore.
item.dc:creator: Livia Albeck-Ripka
item.media:description: A dead fish floats in Lake Merritt, on Monday, in Oakland, Calif.

item.title: U.S. Will Set Aside Monkeypox Vaccines in New Equity Program
item.description: White House officials said an “equity intervention pilot” will get more doses to communities that have been left behind in the nation’s inoculation campaign.
item.dc:creator: Noah Weiland
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:description: A monkeypox vaccination in Tucson, Ariz., this month. A new program the White House announced Tuesday is aimed at increasing access to the shots.

item.title: Solomon Islands Suspends Visits by Foreign Navies, Raising Concerns Over China
item.description: The move comes after top U.S. officials visited the Pacific nation to bolster ties and deliver warnings over its new security agreement with China.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:credit: Matthew Abbott for The New York Times
item.media:description: The U.S. combat ship Oakland visited Honiara, the capital of the Solomon Islands, as part of a ceremony in early August marking the 80th anniversary of battles in World War II.

item.title: Russia’s Occupation of Nuclear Plant Gives Moscow a New Way to Intimidate
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia appears to be using the facility to scare Ukraine’s leaders and warn the West to stay out of the conflict.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger
item.media:credit: Lynsey Addario for The New York Times
item.media:description: Russians say that the shelling near Ukraine’s Zaporizhzhia power plant is coming from Ukrainian forces, and Ukraine’s government insists that Russian forces are responsible.

item.title: Ruby C. Williams, Folk Artist With a Produce Stand, Dies at 94
item.description: Her colorful paintings started out as advertisements for her farm stand in Florida. Before long, her works found their way to art galleries.
item.dc:creator: Neil Genzlinger
item.media:description: The folk artist Ruby C. Williams around 2009 in front of her produce stand in a rural part of Florida, east of Tampa.

item.title: Arizona’s Supreme Court Blocks Election Reform Measure
item.description: The Arizona Free and Fair Elections Act would have established same-day voter registration and prohibited the state Legislature from overturning federal election results.
item.dc:creator: Neil Vigdor
item.media:credit: Adriana Zehbrauskas for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Arizona Supreme Court affirmed a lower court judge’s earlier decision to reject more than 238,000 signatures from the petition to place the measure on the ballot.

item.title: Man Gets 3 Years in Scheme to Sell Bogus Tom Brady Super Bowl Rings
item.description: A New Jersey man cheated an unidentified Patriots player out of his championship ring and then posed as him to order three more engraved with Tom Brady’s last name, federal prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: Michael Levenson
item.media:description: A New England Patriots Super Bowl ring from the championship game played in 2017 is displayed at the Super Bowl Rings exhibit in Indianapolis.

item.title: There Are Now F.E.C. Complaints Against Biden and Trump
item.description: Both parties have now lodged complaints saying the opposing party’s leader ran afoul of election law in not officially declaring 2024 presidential runs.
item.dc:creator: Blake Hounshell
item.media:credit: Al Drago for The New York Times
item.media:description: The complaint against President Biden, filed on Tuesday by Americans for Public Trust, is unlikely to succeed or be resolved quickly.

item.title: Garland Adds Limits at Justice Dept. on Political Activity of Staff
item.description: The department imposed new restrictions on appointees attending political events, a policy change that comes ahead of the midterm elections.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.media:credit: Leigh Vogel for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Justice Department in Washington.

item.title: U.N. Race Panel Sounds the Alarm on Abortion Access in the U.S.
item.description: The influential committee called on the Biden administration to safeguard access for minorities and to address a host of issues on race relations.
item.dc:creator: Nick Cumming-Bruce
item.media:description: Atlanta’s mayor, Andre Dickens, center, was a member of the U.S. delegation appearing during the hearing held by the United Nations’ Committee on the Elimination of Racial Discrimination in Geneva this month.

item.title: Biden Calls Out G.O.P. on Guns, Crime and ‘Sickening’ Attacks on the F.B.I.
item.description: President Biden took what have been political vulnerabilities for the White House — policing and rising crime — and portrayed them as strengths ahead of the congressional elections in November.
item.dc:creator: Zolan Kanno-Youngs
item.media:description: During his trip to Pennsylvania on Tuesday, President Biden highlighted a bipartisan gun bill intended to prevent dangerous people from accessing firearms.

item.title: Paxlovid Cuts Covid Deaths Among Older People, Israeli Study Finds
item.description: Among patients under 65, however, the drug made little difference in hospitalization or death rates.
item.dc:creator: Roni Rabin
item.media:description: According to the new Israeli study, the medication was highly effective when administered to individuals 65 and over.

item.title: Hard Right Stokes Outrage After Search of Mar-a-Lago
item.description: As they did before the Jan. 6 attack on the Capitol, the former president and his allies are fueling anger among supporters.
item.dc:creator: Alan Feuer and Maggie Haberman
item.media:credit: Jamie Kelter Davis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Former President Donald J. Trump has often sought to demonize his adversaries.

item.title: Trump Hires Christopher Kise as Lawyer in Mar-a-Lago Documents Case
item.description: The former president has brought Christopher M. Kise onto his legal team after struggling to find high-profile lawyers willing to work for him on the investigation into his handling of classified material.
item.dc:creator: Maggie Haberman
item.media:description: Christopher M. Kise, seen in 2005, is the former solicitor general of Florida.

item.title: After a Quiet August, Hurricane Forecasters Are Monitoring a Potential Storm
item.description: The disturbance could develop into a tropical storm in the next five days, after the first August in 25 years without a named storm in the Atlantic.
item.dc:creator: Derrick Bryson Taylor
item.media:description: The five-day tropical weather outlook.

item.title: Brutal Heat Wave Expected in California This Week
item.description: A scorcher will bring triple-digit temperatures to much of Central and Southern California through Labor Day, weather officials say.
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.media:credit: Ariana Drehsler for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ocean Beach in San Diego.

item.title: Mississippi Governor Declares Emergency Over Drinking Water Crisis
item.description: In Jackson, residents have long contended with boil-water notices and service disruptions. But now, officials say, the system has been pushed to the brink.
item.dc:creator: Rick Rojas
item.media:credit: Edmund D. Fountain for The New York Times
